title: El Camino Real de los Tejas National Historic Trail: Rancho los Ojuelos
body: Explore This Park    Learn About the Park     Photos & Multimedia     A Photographic Journey of the Trail     A Photographic Journey - Pictures 1-15     Rancho los Ojuelos                  Rancho los Ojuelos        Christopher Talbot       Rancho los Ojuelos, Webb County, Texas This national historic district consists of 13 stone houses (several in ruins) constructed from hewn sandstone blocks, chinked and plastered, ranging from rectangular flat roofed Colonial style buildings to hip roofed two room structures. It was temporarily settled in 1810 by Eugenio Gutierrez who received a grant from the Spanish Crown for two sitios (ca. 8,856 acres). He constructed the ranch headquarters near a large natural spring (ojuelos). This site is a good example of the type of multipurpose hacienda (socio-economic-agricultural-religious establishment) that evolved close to Dolores in South Texas, adjacent to the Río Grande. Time period: Post-1750s Ownership: Private A Photographic Journey of the Trail - NEXT IMAGE PREVIOUS IMAGE
